title.narrative: Green roads for climate resilience and water management

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value: We have uploaded the final report that we have submitted to tmtreports@nuffic.nl on 30/01/2021

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
We proposed to give a 2-weeks training in our proposal. Later, we decided, together with DoLI, to undertake multiple activities (preparatory meetings between MM and DoLI in December 2020, 2-days introductory workshop and road assessments with DoLI and municipalities in February 2020 and the main training in November 2020). The introductory workshop helped us to better tailor the 6-days main training to the local challenges. The initial plan was to provide the main training in between March and August but due to COVID-19, we had to push the schedule couple of time. In November 2020, we successfully organized the 6-days training. Meanwhile, regarding the development of guidelines on ‘springs protection and management’ we helped DoLI to form a Technical Working Committee (TWC) that will work together with MM drafting the guidelines.
Therefore, we state that we were able to adapt to the COVID-19 problematic situation and achieve the objectives of this project by the end of November 2020.

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: DoLI has been strengthened by the TMT

11-10-2021: The objective of this training project was to increase the capacity of the Department of Local Infrastructure (DoLI) and local units (i.e. municipalities) in order to mainstream integrated, gender inclusive and participatory road water management. Organizations strengthened by this training project: 1. Department of Local Infrastructure, DoLI (requesting organization) 2. Godawari Municipality 3. Kirtipur Municipality 4. Panchapuri Municipality 5. Bheriganga Municiaplity 6. Gurbhakot Municipality 7. Bheri Municipality 8. Lekbeshi Municipality

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates

comment.narrative: Create coregroup of female engineers as role models to stimulate others through trainings and events

11-10-2021: We gave special attention to gender with focus on women and marginalized groups participation in road planning, construction and maintenance but also on empowering women engineers in DoLI and municipalities. Apart from the presentations on women inclusion in road development we, further, discussed the gender context and the challenges of women in Nepal. We discussed the Gender and Social Inclusion (GESI) Policy for infrastructure projects in Nepal (e.g., if they participants are aware of this policy, if they use it in their organization, how it is implemented and how to improve it and make it more effective). We also had a discussion with the participants on the Internship program ‘Empowering women engineers’ offered by DRSP since 2007. We asked the participants if this program is still carried out and how it could be better promoted. Finally, participants developed action plans for the inclusion of women in their organizations and field.

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 11-10-2021: We undertook both direct evaluation by asking the participants to fill in an evaluation form and indirect evaluation through observation. The general opinion of the participants was very positive. Through the direct evaluation, we show that the majority of the participants (90%) strongly agreed that the objectives of the training were met, the presenters were engaging, the content of the training was easy to follow, the discussions and groupwork sessions were relevant and helpful, the training was useful and it should be continued for the benefit of DoLI and the municipalities. Through the indirect evaluation, we saw that all participants were very active and happy to share their thoughts and explore the application of the topics discussed in their work.

title.narrative: B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women

comment.narrative: 12-10-2021: As mentioned in B.I.1., we had 21 participants (7 female) in the first introductory workshop in February and another 21 participants (7 female) in the main training in November. However one female doubles up, ie. followed both trainings, hence the change in reported numbers.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative: 12-10-2021: Response: a total of 40 unique participants were trained combined in an introductory and main training. The first training comprised 14 men and 7 women, which was also the case for the second. However two participants from the first also attended the second, hence a total of 40 unique participants were trained (13 female / 27 male). Our apologies for the miscount.

title.narrative: B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment
B.I.3. % of scholarship holders / TMT participants / alumni employed post-study within region and same employer
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value:
The initial plan was to have at least 9 women attending the final main training (November 2020). Unfortunately, 2 women didn’t attend due to illness of their kids. Yet 7 women attended (33%).
Special attention was given on women participation in planning, implementation, and maintenance of roads both through presentation and group work and discussion. The participants come up with the plan on how to include women in the road development and to create employment opportunities for women by suggesting their engagement of them in road construction groups (RCBs) and road maintenance groups (RMGs). They also suggested the participation of women from the planning phase and in bioengineering. Therefore, the group work/discussion session and the answers of the participants to the questionnaire for module 4 helped us to understand the knowledge and skills gained by the participants.

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value:
We undertook an assessment of the experience of participants with the topics on each module at the end of each module. We set assessments for 4 modules namely i. Road Water Management and environmental practices for Nepal; ii. Technical know-how and skills on low-cost, high impact solution-how to do it?; iii. Capacity Building and Knowledge management-how to support local units?; & iv. Inclusion through governance. At the start of each module, we shared questions with the participants. At the end of each module, we discussed the participants’ answers to those questions. This helped us to make sure that the topics discussed under each module were well-understood by **all participants**.
​
